Tonight's topic is
"Shifts in the Sand--

8.11.text:
We're so pleased to

18.22.text:
and Director of the Gulf

23.02.text:

energy and economics, and
Gulf and energy policy.

58.12.text:

66.53.text:
Given the changes

71.94.text:

this will be a very

116.82.text:
and thank you very much

143.44.text:
so don't expect an

'cause you're not

154.92.text:
If I could say

158.76.text:

163.66.text:
As you can tell
from my accent,

168.64.text:
I've been in the United States
for coming up 11 years.

175.48.text:
I am now, along with my family,

and as my colleagues joke with

186.82.text:
whether I'm an American or not

But Washington is a very

197.83.text:
and it's an interesting
place to try to jumpstart

206.21.text:
But it's also very nice to

211.68.text:
How did I get involved
in Saudi Arabia?

215.05.text:
Let me start by saying I've
never been to Saudi Arabia.

221.19.text:
That may be
surprising to you,

223.16.text:
but there's a very
simple reason for that,

225.12.text:
which is that if you write
about the Saudi royal family,

229.13.text:
it's not a quick way of getting
a visa to Saudi Arabia.

234.40.text:
And I write about the
Saudi royal family.

237.20.text:
A very good Saudi friend
of mine once said to me--

240.01.text:
he said, "We talk about
the Saudi royal family

243.38.text:
"and what's going
on all the time.

249.35.text:

to write it down?"

252.12.text:
So, you give the
obvious answer--

254.39.text:
"Well, I come from a different
intellectual tradition

259.33.text:
I got involved in
Saudi Arabia

261.36.text:
because when I was at
the "Financial Times,"

266.23.text:
I had some sabbatical
leave coming up.

269.44.text:
The "Financial Times" was
very generous in those days,

272.54.text:
and gave six weeks leave
every five years.

276.68.text:
And I wanted to make use
of some sabbatical leave

281.91.text:
and I decided I wanted
to go to Washington

289.12.text:
actually to the Washington
Institute for Near East Policy,

294.56.text:
And I went out to lunch with
a friend of mine in London

298.00.text:
who worked for BP,
the major oil company.

302.87.text:
And I said, "I've got
this opportunity,

307.24.text:
"but I have to
think of an idea,

312.08.text:
And the friend said-- and
this was in the early 1990s,

317.28.text:
when the then-King Fahd
had recently issued

322.49.text:
a basic law which
was the first time

325.02.text:
that the essence of
the Saudi Constitution

331.20.text:
And my friend said in
King Fahd's latest basic law,

335.70.text:
he says for the first time what
we all knew verbally anyway,

339.94.text:
which was that the
King of Saudi Arabia

343.14.text:
would be from the sons and
grandsons of the founder

348.51.text:
of Saudi Arabia, a man
called "King Abdulaziz."

352.02.text:
He died in 1953 and was
known by the British,

359.03.text:
and traditionally these days,
he's known as "Ibn Saud."

363.50.text:
And my friend said to me,
"Why don't you make a study

370.77.text:
Sp I went away and wrote
a two-page proposal--

378.28.text:
I said I wanted to study
succession in Saudi Arabia.

383.85.text:
I thought it was
an interesting topic.

386.52.text:
Saudi Arabia is
an important place

389.46.text:
and I thought
what I would do

393.56.text:
would be to go and ask former
British and American diplomats,

407.34.text:
people who had
had direct contact

409.58.text:
with Saudi Arabia and some
sort of direct familiarity

419.79.text:
about what they knew
about the royal family.

423.19.text:
And the essence of what
I would be asking was,

426.49.text:
"How had succession
happened in the past?

430.10.text:

in the future?

434.43.text:

we should look out for

444.11.text:
"And what, if anything, should
Britain and the United States

451.18.text:
"do to try and impact on
succession in Saudi Arabia

457.59.text:
"to ensure that it works,
frankly, favorably

465.36.text:
And I got my fellowship and
I went around interviewing.

472.94.text:
I had a hit list
of about 35 people

476.71.text:
who I wrote to, to say,
"Can I come and talk to you,

486.85.text:
And I brought their
answers together--

491.79.text:
to truncate quite
a long story--

494.36.text:
and it was published eventually
by the Washington Institute,

497.96.text:
called, "After King Fahd--
Succession in Saudi Arabia."

503.00.text:
It was, at least in
think tank terms, a bestseller.

511.31.text:
and indeed, it
was being sold

515.82.text:
before it had
actually been printed,

517.58.text:
which, again, in think tank
terms, is fairly extraordinary.

521.12.text:
Subsequently, in 2009,
I wrote another study

528.09.text:
And this one was called,
"After King Abdullah--

533.70.text:
And yes, I am supposed to
be working on something

537.60.text:
called "After King Salman--

541.37.text:
but I have to say that progress
on this particular work

545.18.text:
is rather slow and
I'm being distracted

548.05.text:
by all sorts of
day-by-day events

551.45.text:
which seem to me
much more important

557.66.text:
of what it might
all be about.

560.49.text:
Let me explain to you why
Saudi Arabia is important

570.00.text:
Let me-- ah, great--
it's always pleasing

576.24.text:
and the slide you want
to come up, comes up.

582.65.text:
Saudi Arabia-- this is a
familiar enough map to me.

589.69.text:
My institute office walls
are covered with maps,

598.50.text:
Saudi Arabia is at the very
center of the Middle East.

605.84.text:
But there are many
other countries

610.58.text:
And what I'd like you
to think of at the moment

615.18.text:
is that, in fact,
Saudi Arabia is surrounded

621.29.text:
many of which it
has land borders--

624.19.text:
Yemen, Oman, the UAE,
Qatar, Bharain--

628.03.text:
at least it's joined by
a causeway with Bharain--

637.70.text:
and if you are in the
top left-hand corner

642.34.text:
of Saudi Arabia and
you've got good eyesight,

645.81.text:
you could probably
see Israel, as well.

650.15.text:
And the distinguishing
feature of these neighbors

653.05.text:
is it's made up of neighbors
which are usually smaller

657.42.text:
than Saudi Arabia, and
some of which it likes

660.59.text:
and some of which
it doesn't like.

663.80.text:
But what this
comes down to,

667.00.text:
in the way that the Saudis
look at themselves

670.60.text:
is that Saudi Arabia has
three different perspectives

678.88.text:
The first one is-- or the
one which I'll list first--

682.52.text:
is that it sees itself as the
leader of the Islamic world

688.19.text:
by virtue of
being the place

692.73.text:
where the two holy cities
of Mecca and Medina are.

701.47.text:
Maybe it doesn't have
a (indistinct) on it,

703.84.text:
but Mecca and Medina are
on the Red Sea coast,

708.41.text:
And it is the leader
of the Islamic world.

714.01.text:
It is also a leader,
if not the leader,

720.29.text:
And from the perspective
that we usually look at it

725.22.text:
or all too often
we look at it,

727.26.text:
is that it's a leader
of the energy world

730.40.text:
by virtue of having,
by most calculations,

735.50.text:
the world's largest
reserves of oil.

741.21.text:
For those pedants
who think that Venezuela

744.88.text:
has larger reserves,
you're absolutely right,

748.21.text:
except Venezuela's
reserves are tar sands

751.85.text:
which are difficult to get
at and expensive to get at.

755.55.text:
Saudi Arabia's oil is
comparatively cheap to get at.

761.39.text:
And Saudi Arabia,
on top of that,

762.90.text:
has huge oil production and
spare capacity as well.

767.67.text:
Now, of these three
different roles,

770.37.text:
Saudi Arabia considers
its most important role

775.34.text:
to be the leader of
the Islamic world.

780.01.text:
This was a straightforward
thing to be, once.

786.75.text:
It required you to organize
the Hajj pilgrimage

790.16.text:
and facilitate pilgrims
not only coming at the time

794.36.text:
for the Hajj, but
also at other times

798.50.text:
And Saudi Arabia prides
itself on doing this well

801.73.text:
and is enormously embarrassed
when things go wrong.

805.34.text:
These days, that leadership
of the Islamic world

810.04.text:
is, from a Saudi
point of view--

813.68.text:
and it's worse than that--
is being contested by Iran.

819.99.text:
Iran, of course, is made
up of Shiite Muslims,

825.76.text:
a minority in the
greater Islamic world.

830.80.text:
And Saudi Arabia-- uh, the
Saudis are Sunni Muslims.

836.27.text:
But Iran is awkward,
doesn't like Saudi Arabia,

842.17.text:
and wants to delegitimize
itself as the leader

850.12.text:
And the narrative which
I think works best

855.29.text:
for trying to understand
the last few decades

858.86.text:
of Middle East history is
since the Iranian Revolution,

865.16.text:
there has been a
perpetual competition

870.04.text:
for influence between
Saudi Arabia and Iran.

875.44.text:
And I also think that this
is the particular thing

879.11.text:
which is going to be a
dominant issue going forward--

882.92.text:
the tension between
Saudi Arabia and Iran.

888.79.text:
Now, the work I do-- this is
the sketch, the overall sketch.

894.83.text:
I want to come down from
30,000 feet to talk to you

901.37.text:
a little about the
particular work that I do

907.37.text:
And this is because politics
as such don't exist

915.18.text:
There isn't a president
who's going to be there

917.08.text:
for four years, replaced
by another president,

920.29.text:
or having another
term for four years.

923.26.text:
Saudi Arabia is about
the Saudi royal family.

926.73.text:
The Saudi royal family
rules Saudi Arabia,

932.00.text:
they are the history
of Saudi Arabia.

934.67.text:
They think they are the
future of Saudi Arabia.

938.50.text:
They hope they are the
future of Saudi Arabia.

942.31.text:
But Saudi Arabia,
as I've suggested,

944.64.text:
is in a tough neighborhood,
and so this isn't something

949.88.text:
which can be taken
totally for granted.

952.45.text:
And I'm going to give
you a bit of a guide

954.82.text:
of what to look for
over the next few years

959.93.text:
when you're reading stories
about Saudi Arabia

962.76.text:
in the newspapers, or
watching them on television.

965.56.text:
And I want you to be able
to say, "Ah, I remember

972.40.text:
"It seemed a bit
obscure at the time,

974.37.text:
"but it all fits
into a pattern."

981.85.text:
the main character,
the Saudi royal family,

987.92.text:
is made up of a huge
number of princes--

You will note that I
didn't use the expression

997.83.text:

But in the great

1002.94.text:
princesses don't count

1006.34.text:
This is a simple
statement of fact.

1010.61.text:

perhaps, in the Q and A.

1014.88.text:
But it's the men who count,
and it's the top men who count.

1021.55.text:
The ones I want to introduce
you to this evening,

1025.89.text:
by virtue of what's
going on now.

1031.86.text:
In order to understand
what's going on now,

1033.53.text:
you have to wind the

1035.90.text:
to what was going
on beforehand.

1043.58.text:
it wasn't ruled

1050.75.text:
of King Salman, the

And at that time, Salman

1059.53.text:

1068.83.text:
And the politics of this

1071.97.text:

1083.75.text:
He has been something

1088.19.text:

1094.26.text:
At which point,

1105.47.text:
for Muqrin, he made

1117.42.text:

1130.16.text:

1133.63.text:

before Salman

1138.84.text:
relieved Muqrin of his

1146.45.text:
So from April 2015

1154.79.text:

and has the physical

1168.90.text:
He uses a walking stick

1183.98.text:
and then, he-- in April 2015,
having got rid of Muqrin,

prince, Muhammad bin Nayef,

1194.29.text:

1197.23.text:
That was significant

1199.06.text:
because this was going

1208.07.text:
as opposed to a son

1221.09.text:

1226.36.text:
who at the time was
29 years old or something.

1237.47.text:
a mere child in
House of Saud terms,

1249.45.text:
Too many Muhammads,

1253.15.text:
Well, for simplicity sake,
we call the first Muhammad MbN

1262.29.text:
And even the Saudis refer to

1267.30.text:

1274.87.text:
And Not only are they
the king, crown prince,

1280.55.text:
deputy crown prince, there
are other responsibilities

1285.55.text:
The king is the

1290.46.text:
So he chairs the weekly

1295.53.text:

1306.54.text:

And MbS is also the

1320.19.text:
and the head of

1324.59.text:
Now, this gets a

but MbN is not MbS's

There's politics going on at

1347.95.text:
So those are the

1351.45.text:
but by listing them as

1353.72.text:
it enables me to bring in

1361.26.text:
who is-- "bin" means "son of"
so he's the son

1370.30.text:
And Mitab bin Abdullah,
when his father was king,

1377.44.text:
which is a sort of

If you don't trust

1389.69.text:
where there have been

1393.13.text:
that's just the defensive

1397.10.text:
Mitab bin Adbullah was in

1402.93.text:
He's still in charge
of the National Guard

1407.67.text:
But any hope that his father
might had that his son Mitab

1412.41.text:
might one day be king
vanished essentially

1421.85.text:
This is where it becomes--
can become slightly dramatic.

1426.66.text:
And it's the sort of thing that
I'm sure the Saudi Embassy

1429.93.text:
in Washington doesn't
even like being discussed,

1434.30.text:
never mind being written
down and put on a slide.

1439.07.text:
But I developed this
slide a year or so ago

1444.21.text:
because I was asked to
give a presentation

1447.65.text:
on what might happen
in Saudi Arabia

1450.28.text:
and I realized there
were a variety of options,

1456.29.text:
which had to be taken
seriously as possibilities,

1461.36.text:
that at least had
to be thought about.

1465.46.text:
The obvious one is
King Salman dies.

1469.63.text:
When he's going to
die is a question.

1473.37.text:
He might go on forever, but
somehow, I don't think so.

1480.58.text:
Another one is that King Salman
could become incapacitated.

1488.62.text:
When he meets foreign
dignitaries, in front of him,

1493.73.text:
partly obscured by huge
floral arrangement, is an iPad.

1498.83.text:
The system is that an aide
sitting off to one side

1502.67.text:
listens to what the questions
the king is being asked

1505.90.text:
and hammers away
on the keyboard

1508.04.text:
and up pops the answer
on the king's iPad

1512.04.text:
for him to then respond
to the dignitary

1518.12.text:
I kid you not-- this is
the way that it is done.

1524.02.text:
There's also the possibility
that Muhammad bin Nayef,

1529.29.text:
the crown prince, could die
or become incapacitated.

1535.17.text:
In recent photographs, he
looks quite hale and hearty.

1539.64.text:
But a year or so ago,
he was looking very sick,

1551.28.text:
He is a man who once survived
a suicide bomb attack

1559.12.text:
who was standing next
to him at the time.

1561.76.text:
But might have-- and the
only physical injury

1566.77.text:
for Muhammad bin Nayef
was a cut finger.

1569.90.text:
But I suspect there was this
degree of mental stress.

1574.71.text:
Most of us would have a
degree of mental stress

1576.84.text:
if a suicide bomber blew
themselves up alongside up.

1581.38.text:
Muhammad bin Nayef is said to
be addicted to pain killers.

1586.95.text:
but it's been reported
in the press anyway.

1590.96.text:
He could also--
I want to be dramatic

1597.60.text:
Assassination has
happened in Saudi Arabia.

1605.60.text:
one of the earlier kings,
was assassinated.

1608.51.text:
He was assassinated by a
deranged nephew, a prince.

1618.38.text:
Now, if the king wants
to really play politics,

1622.19.text:
he's got to push
Muhammad bin Nayef to one side.

1627.76.text:
And so, in the same
way that King Salman

1630.50.text:
got rid of Muqrin, who was

1634.70.text:
if you've got rid
of one crown prince,

1636.67.text:
you might reckon you can get

1640.14.text:
Whether you could get away
with it in family terms

1644.11.text:
But this is a possibility
which has to be acknowledged.

1649.95.text:
And an aspect of that is
that the king could abdicate,

1657.92.text:
which is unheard of
in Saudi terms,

1661.49.text:
but I suppose is
a possibility.

1664.96.text:
And he could-- in abdicating,
he could say,

1668.00.text:
"I want Muhammad bin Salman
to be the next king."

1672.94.text:
I can't imagine that
Muhammad bin Nayef

1674.97.text:
would be pleased by this,
but I'm not sure

1678.51.text:
in the circumstances whether

1682.68.text:
And then-- or a half measure
there would be for the king

1688.32.text:
to appoint MbS
as prime minister.

1691.92.text:
So the king would
still be king

1696.43.text:
and the crown prince would
still be crown prince,

1700.37.text:
chief government role
of prime minister

1702.43.text:
could have been given
to somebody else,

1704.50.text:
the young man
Muhammad bin Salman.

1709.81.text:
It might well be
that somebody thinks

1712.98.text:
that Muhammad bin Salman
is such a pain

1716.01.text:
that "we've got to

1717.35.text:
which is why I've included
the possibility

of his assassination
there, as well.

1722.92.text:
Sometimes, I feel as

the plot of a

And it might well
be that I am,

And then-- and this gets
a wee bit technical,

1739.57.text:
but if the king could
essentially sack

Mitab bin Abdullah as the
head of the Saudi guard,
